transformed_texts:
To be honest, I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes. Their views on certain issues might be causing them to lose followers. I think this is because the Church isn't very accepting of many things. For instance, when it comes to gay marriages, abortions, and birth control, the Church has very strong views, but they may be a bit outdated. If they adapted to a more modern perspective, they'd likely worry less about losing their following.

I've noticed that some people are starting to turn against the Church due to their stance on these issues. This is because people have different views on these subjects, and they feel that the Church is holding the wrong views. For example, if someone supports abortion, they might not feel comfortable in a community where it's seen as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone believes in gay marriage, they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't agree with that.

It's interesting to think about why the Church is against things like female priests and priests being married. However, I'm not sure if that would have prevented the issues they're facing. Maybe if priests were allowed to be married or if women could be priests, things would be different, but I'm not convinced it would have made a significant difference.

I don't see why priests can't be married, considering the Church views them as being married to God and devoted to their lives as priests. It's like any other job - people have their professional lives and their personal lives. The fact that priests can't have both seems outdated.

Honestly, I have to admit that I've given this a lot of thought, and I don't actually have an issue with gay marriage. In my opinion, people's sexual orientation isn't something they can consciously choose, so I don't think they should be held accountable for it. It seems unfair to deny two people of the same sex the right to get married just because of their sexual orientation. I mean, think about it - people are born with their sexual orientation, just like I'm straight and others are gay. It's not something they can switch or change at will. I don't think the government should be involved in this, as it's not a matter of security or morality - it's a personal issue that doesn't concern them. To me, it's just about treating people with respect and allowing them to live their lives as they are. I don't think the government should be able to dictate who can and can't get married based on their orientation. It just doesn't seem right to me.

In fact, it's kind of simple - the government shouldn't interfere with people's personal lives unless it affects the country's security or well-being. But this isn't about that. It's about two people loving each other and wanting to get married. I don't think the government should be in a position to deny them that. It's just common sense, you know? Let people be who they are and live their lives without the government breathing down their necks. It's really not that complicated.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that I think it's wrong to deny gay people the right to get married. It's just basic human decency. They shouldn't be punished for being who they are, and the government shouldn't be involved in their personal lives. It's as simple as that.

I'm not going to sugarcoat it - I think the government is overstepping its bounds by trying to dictate who can and can't get married. It's not their call. People should be free to love who they want and get married to whoever they choose, without the government getting in the way.

I'm not going to dwell on this anymore, but I just wanted to share my thoughts. I hope that makes sense.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized because, honestly, there's no valid reason not to. People often think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but that's just not true. It's like comparing apples and oranges - they're two distinct things that can't be equated. Each side of the coin is unique, and it's not fair to judge one over the other. The truth is, homosexual couples have the same rights as everyone else, like having their partner by their side in times of need, even in a hospital or when it comes to tax laws and healthcare benefits.

It's ridiculous that partners in a same-sex relationship can't be considered family in the eyes of the law. They're committed to each other, and that's what matters most. Scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same success rates and satisfaction in their relationships as heterosexual couples, which is a clear indication that love is love, regardless of orientation.

The problem lies in the fact that homosexual couples are asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government, not a church ceremony. If we're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are no different from straight couples in many ways, like the roles they play in their relationships.

Of course, there are concerns about adoption, community acceptance, and the impact on children, but these are just new issues that we're still learning about. However, it's hard to deny the fact that children from gay parents are just as capable and deserving of love and respect as any other child. In fact, some schools in cities like New York City even have special programs for kids from gay parents because they face bullying and harassment in public schools.

The real issue is that the government should take a stand on this matter and make gay marriage legal nationwide. The current amendment opposing it is a clear example of hypocrisy, as it goes against the principles of equality and freedom that America claims to uphold. The controversy surrounding the "under God" pledge shows that people are willing to challenge laws that enforce religious standards, so why not apply the same logic to gay marriage?

One of the main reasons people are against gay marriage is the misconception that being gay is a result of psychological damage or a personality defect. However, the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims, and it's time we listen to the experts rather than popular opinion or personal biases. If we did, we'd see the world in a different light and recognize the beauty of love in all its forms.

Okay, let's get this straight. I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer, and I want to make one thing clear: just because a drug is illegal doesn't necessarily mean it's bad. I mean, think about it - there are plenty of prescription meds that are controlled substances, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets. We use them all the time to help people, and that's exactly what I think we should be doing with marijuana.

It's not like marijuana is that different from other substances that are abused, like alcohol. Sure, abusing it can lead to problems, but so can abusing alcohol. It's a tough one, I'll admit it. But I think we should take a step back and look at the benefits of marijuana. If we could remove the stigma around it, people might use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes. It's not some evil substance like heroin or cocaine - it's got its own set of risks and benefits.

If we're going to make it available to the public, it shouldn't be all or nothing. A gradual approach might work better, but first, we need to change the way people think about marijuana. It's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, and if we can get past that, maybe we can use it to help people instead of shunning it. That's my two cents, anyway.

I think the church has really adapted to the 21st century, it's not as strict as it used to be. I've noticed this change since I was a kid, going to church every Sunday, dressed in my cute little outfit and matching accessories. I went to a private school and church was a big part of my weekend routine, seeing my friends there was always a highlight. Now, they've introduced a shorter mass for teenagers, which is only 30 minutes long, and people dress in casual attire, especially during summer. It's become more laid-back, even at morning masses where I used to dress up, now people wear jeans and khakis. I think this shift is noticeable, it's the biggest change I've seen. As for other things, that's pretty much it, I don't really know the church's politics, but that's my take on it. 

Regarding the accusations of pedophilia against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented these situations. There are men who are married and still become pedophiles, it's not about their marital status. It's the individual's choice to become a priest, and there are other religions where they can be married. If someone wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different faith. I think pedophilia is rooted in genetics, people are born with these tendencies, and it's not something that can be hidden or changed through marriage. The church can't prevent something that's innate, and if they knew about it and covered it up, that's unacceptable. However, I don't think they always knew. As for other thoughts on the Catholic church, I don't really have any.

(laughs) 
At first, I was somewhat okay with the idea, but I think the country was still reeling from the aftermath of the September 11th attacks. It seemed like we entered Iraq using it as a pretext, with various reasons leading us into the conflict. I believe the Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, which has since been proven false.

This really bothered me, and the Iraq war just gets my blood boiling. It seems like the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and still hasn't taken responsibility for those lies. Even Colin Powell, who gave that pivotal speech at the UN, now admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time he presented it. To me, that's a serious abuse of power and an impeachable offense.

I think the Bush administration has a disregard for the constitution and has been working to undermine it since 9/11. They came into office with a clear intention to go to war. When I think back to that time, it's clear that the administration had it out for Saddam Hussein, partly due to a grudge carried over from his dad's administration, and also to expand our energy supply – which is a very underhanded approach.

I'm not sure how long this can go on, but I believe withdrawing now could be problematic, as there's a good chance the country would descend into civil war, resulting in more deaths. The current alternative, where the UN and US are considering a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order, doesn't seem like a great idea to me. This could create more long-term issues, particularly with Iraq's sovereignty, as it appears the interim government is disintegrating. The news reports suggest the Parliament is ineffective, and the Prime Minister has little control over the situation.

With groups like Mugtada al-Sadr's party holding significant power in the Iraqi Parliament and radical elements vying for control, the political process is experiencing significant friction. I'm not sure I can articulate all the issues in polite conversation, but it's clear this is a complex and messy situation.

I'm really struggling to find the right words on this. Okay, let's get the basics out of the way first. To be honest, I don't know much about the Iraq War. I mean, it wasn't officially declared as a war, which already makes it tricky to discuss. I think it started as a sort of revenge for 9/11, targeting the people we believed were responsible. But, to be frank, I don't follow this closely, and I'm not sure about all the details. As far as I understand, we're trying to build a democracy in Iraq, making it more like the US, and also securing oil resources. However, this approach is causing a lot of tension and distress.

We're stuck between a rock and a hard place. If we stay, we'll be tasked with building a democracy, which can't be done overnight, and it'll take a lot of time and effort. But, if we leave, the Iraqis will be left to deal with the mess we created, and they'll blame us for it. I'm not sure what the right course of action is, to be honest.

This topic is really challenging for me because I don't know enough about it, and I'm not sure where to start. If you have any points you'd like me to focus on, I'd appreciate it.

To be honest, I think the war should be considered over, not just because of the lack of a formal declaration, but also because it's become more about showing our power and military might than achieving a genuine goal. It's like we're using force to prove a point, rather than working towards a solution.

I'm torn, though. On one hand, I think we should help the Iraqis, but on the other, I worry about the resources we're wasting and the potential consequences of our actions. I feel sorry for President Bush, as this war is making him look really bad, much like the Vietnam War did. It's like history is repeating itself.

It's hard for me to say whether I want the war to end or continue, because I think about all the families who have loved ones fighting in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. However, I also think that our presence is causing more harm than good, as we're disrupting their culture and creating more divisions among the different groups in Iraq. I worry that our attempts to impose our way of life on them will only lead to more resentment and hatred towards the US.

In the end, I think this conflict will drag on for years to come, and it's hard to see a clear solution. That's about all I have to say on the matter.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for the government to make it a law or even recognize it as legal. I believe it's up to the churches to decide, especially considering the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. It's a pretty straightforward principle that's been set in stone, and I think trying to impose any kind of authority over it would be a direct defiance of what's already been established.

To me, allowing government to dictate what churches can and can't make illegal is essentially favoring one church's beliefs over another. It's clear that a lot of Catholics and Christians are against it, and it's mainly being opposed in certain areas like Boston. I don't think it's the government's place to decide what's acceptable or not within the church.

The separation of church and state is a fundamental aspect of the constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. I think trying to amend the constitution to restrict this principle would be wrong and contradict the existing values. It's one of the few amendments that would actually restrict the people rather than limiting government power, which is exactly the opposite of what it's supposed to do.

Personally, I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I believe the president's push for an amendment is mainly driven by his own Catholic beliefs and personal views. It's showing a preference for one religion over others, which I don't think is fair. The churches should be the ones making these decisions, not the government. There's no clear reasoning behind this amendment other than personal opinions, and I don't see how it would benefit the economy or society. Okay, so let's talk about the war in Iraq. I've been thinking, and I don't think the government was entirely honest with the American people about the reasons for going to war before invading Iraq. They tried to link it to the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but it's not like they were directly related. The government played on the emotions of the American people, and that's a big part of why the invasion started in 2003. As someone who's generally against war, especially preemptive strikes, I was strongly opposed to this one.

It's kind of like the Vietnam War all over again - the government should have learned from past mistakes. A huge number of American soldiers have died in this war, which is incredibly sad. What they did was remove the Iraqi government, and I don't think the US government was ready for the power vacuum and chaos that followed. They're trying to install democracy, just like they did in Vietnam, but it's not that easy. It's a long and hard process, and the US government underestimated the challenges they'd face.

No matter how many Iraqis wanted the US to intervene, there are still tons of insurgents, and it's hard to defeat them when you're fighting the citizens of the country, not an actual army. I think the government should have planned for all possible outcomes before invading, but they weren't prepared for the aftermath. We're still there in 2006, and many American troops are still dying. It's a long process to train the Iraqi troops and police forces to take care of their own country, and I think the US government was naive to think it would be a quick and easy success.

We shouldn't have gone to war in the first place, but if we were going to do it, we should have been more honest with ourselves and the American people about the risks and challenges involved. It's not like democracy is something that can be easily imposed on a country; it's a long and difficult process, as we learned in our own country's history. The US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do, but it's not.

It's a tough decision to make, especially when you think about all the American lives lost and the country's resources being spent. Once you're in, it's hard to leave, especially when you've taken away someone else's government and way of life. We should try to see it through, but at the same time, there's a limit to how much we can risk American lives for the sake of a free, democratic Iraq. If we're really committed to spreading democracy, why not do it in other countries too? The truth is, it's often about oil and control of resources. The whole thing about Iraq having WMDs was a big factor in the decision to go to war, but no WMDs were ever found, and we're not doing anything about North Korea, which we know has WMDs. It seems like the US government is not being thorough or honest enough in its decision-making.

I just hope the war ends soon and there's peace in Iraq, but I'm not optimistic. It's not looking good.

I'm thinking about gay marriage, and I've always been on board with the idea. To me, it comes down to personal preference, and with recent studies showing that it might be biological rather than a social construct, it just doesn't seem right to deny people the right because of something they can't control. I think it's inhumane to do so. As someone who's always advocated for gay marriage, I don't think the government should have a say in it – it's a personal, household issue. In my neighborhood, I've seen openly gay couples living just like any other family. They walk their dogs, live their lives, and it's clear that their relationship is no different from anyone else's.

It's ridiculous that politicians, like Bush, think they can dictate what marriage means. I've read and heard from various sources that research suggests homosexuality might be linked to a chemical imbalance in the brain, which is something people are born with, not something they choose. It's not like growing up in a certain environment or with certain family dynamics determines someone's sexual orientation.

The thing is, if a straight couple wants to get married, they can do it privately, without anyone knowing, but if a gay couple wants to do the same, it's all over the news. That's just not right. I think marriage should be a private, personal thing, not something that's thrust into the public domain.

Honestly, I don't know where to start with this.  When you post something online, it's out there for everyone to see. It's completely public knowledge. You can't just put something out there without considering how others might react. As an R.A., I've already dealt with this kind of situation before. Once you post something, it's going to influence people's opinions about you. If you start talking about violence or sensitive topics, someone's bound to take it seriously. You can't just post that kind of thing online because it's seen by everyone. If you're friends with someone on Myspace or Facebook, you'll get their bulletin, and if someone's concerned enough to report it, the school has to act. They can't just ignore it, especially if there's a risk of something bad happening. On the other hand, it's hard to know what's real and what's just a joke, especially when people can be careless with their online posts. 

What happened here was that someone overheard something in school, reported it, and when we found out who the person was, they looked at their social media and found some posts that might have been meant as a joke but took on a different tone in light of the situation. When you post something online, there's no such thing as privacy. If you don't want people to see it, don't post it. You can't control how people think or what they take seriously. I don't think school officials should be friends with their students on social media or snooping around their profiles, but if something's brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously. If it's not, then it's a different story. I also don't think teachers should make fake accounts to friend their students – it's the same thing. As an R.A., I don't want to know about my residents' private lives, especially if they post about it online. That's not my place to know, and it's not something I'd want to deal with.

To be honest, I think this war has dragged on for far too long. Originally, the goal was to bring democracy to a nation that desperately needed it. However, it seems like we've lost sight of that purpose and are now possibly fighting just to prove our military superiority.

I have to wonder if the true motives behind the war were genuine from the start, considering George Bush's previous conflicts with Saddam Hussein. If our initial goal was to bring democracy to a country with a flawed government system, then that would have been a justifiable reason. But if there were personal interests at play, I think that would have been unfair.

In my opinion, we made our point clear in the first few months of the war - it was a powerful statement. But continuing the conflict for over a year, even years, seems excessive. If our intention was to give people living under a tyrant a chance for freedom, that's a noble cause, and I think that's a good reason to go to war. However, I believe our reasons have been distorted and misinterpreted over time, and it seems like we're fighting just to say we're fighting.

I genuinely think it's time to call an end to this war. The Iraqi government should take responsibility for its own affairs, and it's clear that time has come. We're spending billions of dollars on this conflict, money that could be better spent on our own problems, such as poverty, inadequate public services, and healthcare. It's staggering to think that we're allocating such a large portion of our budget to war efforts, which have lost their initial purpose.

In my opinion, war should not be a long-term investment. We have pressing issues on our own turf, such as crumbling infrastructure, underfunded schools, and healthcare. It's heartbreaking to see our citizens being killed in a foreign war that we've lost sight of its cause. I think that's the harsh reality we need to face.

To clarify, something stopped happening because someone went online and saw a certain post.
Okay, so you know how on Myspace, if you post something, it's pretty much available to everyone who's connected to you?
I mean, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, they can see your profile, and you've basically given them permission to do so by accepting them as a friend.
So, anytime you put information on the internet, it's likely that a lot of people will see it.
In this case, I think it was good that someone saw that post and was able to prevent a potentially serious situation from arising.

However, this raises some tough questions. I mean, it's not feasible for just one person to be constantly monitoring everyone's online profiles to prevent problems. That would be a form of discrimination if they're only targeting certain individuals. I don't think it's right to have someone's job be to sift through people's online profiles, unless they have a good reason to do so, like if they actually found something suspicious.
It's all about the context - were they just randomly looking through profiles or were they actively searching for something?
I'm not sure what the best approach is.

Personally, I have a Facebook account and it bothers me that there are people out there who can see my information. I've seen a report on TV about someone who was able to gather information about someone online and even convince them to meet with him. It's scary to think about how easily people can access personal info and use it for malicious purposes. I've even had people from my classes IM me, despite not knowing my username, and it's hard to know who's really behind the screen. They can see my interests, my class schedule, my friends, and even photos. I try to limit what I post, but at the same time, I want to be able to connect with friends online. It's a delicate balance.

I've heard that some schools have banned students from having Myspace accounts, but I'm not sure how they have the authority to do so. That seems like a privacy issue to me, but I'm not sure how they got the right to dictate what their students can and can't do online.

That's all I can think of for now.

I'm a bit hesitant to bring this up, but I'll go ahead and discuss my thoughts on the Iraq War. I feel a bit hypocritical saying this, as I don't want to jump on the bandwagon of people who claim they were against it from the start. However, it's been made clear by now that this invasion was a bad idea, with most people, including the administration, acknowledging this in hindsight.

Recent polls have shown that around 75-80% of the global population, 80% of Iraqis, and even 70% of US troops stationed in the country believe that the war was a poor decision. This suggests that a significant majority of people, both at home and abroad, think it was a mistake.

The situation has been a disaster from the very beginning, and pulling out now will also be challenging. The cultural differences between the US and Middle Eastern countries are vast, making it difficult for the US to impose its views and values on the region. The idea of forcing democracy on a culture that doesn't naturally adopt it is misguided.

While it's true that Saddam was a bad leader, we need to weigh the pros and cons before invading a country that's likely to become a disaster. The quicksand-like situation we've created in Iraq is a prime example of this. I don't see a compelling reason for the US to stay in Iraq any longer than necessary.

The administration might have some hopeful ideas about why we should stay, but I haven't seen a clear, legitimate reason to justify our continued presence. If they want to withdraw gradually, over a year or more, I wouldn't have a problem with that. However, I don't understand why we can't leave now.

Interestingly, a significant majority of Iraqis – around 80% – think we should leave within a year, with a quarter of them wanting us to leave immediately. These are the people we're trying to help, yet they're telling us to leave. This suggests they might know better than us, and if we ask them to leave, we can say we respected their wishes, even if things don't go well after that.

If we decide to help them after leaving, at least we'll be seen as trying to make amends, even if we're not perfect. We can't change our past mistakes, but we can try to make things better in the future. It's not about being the "good guys" in the Middle East, but about avoiding further catastrophe.

I have to agree that gender discrimination is still a significant issue in the United States. It's not just a women's problem, though; I believe it also affects men in certain fields. You see, in many industries, people still struggle with finding equality, especially when it comes to working under a woman. This is largely due to societal norms that have been ingrained for a long time. 

For example, women are often held back from promotions because of these stereotypes, despite having the qualifications for the job. It's also common for men to face judgment when they choose to be stay-at-home dads. People might think it's unusual for men to prioritize childcare, and it can be tough for them to break free from these expectations. I also think that men in the fashion industry often face prejudice if they're not 'typical' or don't fit the mold of what people expect. 

The problem is that changing this mindset takes time, and it's slow progress. However, we've made significant strides, especially with more women taking on leadership roles and becoming CEOs. As people become more accepting of these changes, it's becoming more common to see men staying home with their kids and women being the breadwinners. It's also helping to break down stereotypes in the fashion industry, where people are starting to take men in fashion seriously, regardless of their style or background.

I guess the key is to promote understanding and acceptance without being too pushy or aggressive. If we force people to change their views too quickly, they'll resist. We're at a good point now where we're starting to see progress, and I'm not sure what more we can do that hasn't already been done. People are still discriminated against based on their background, education, and even their speech patterns, which can be just as limiting as gender bias. It's not just about promoting equality between genders; it's also about recognizing and addressing other forms of prejudice that exist in our society.

Alright, so decriminalizing marijuana isn't the same as legalizing it; it just means that it's been reduced from a criminal offense to a more of a traffic ticket kind of thing. You get cited but not arrested. Now, when it comes to things like job interviews, that sort of thing, the ramifications might not be as bad as they would be with a full-fledged drug charge. But even though decriminalization takes away some of the harsher consequences, it doesn't eliminate them entirely. People still worry about how this will affect their future, and that's valid. On the other hand, arresting and prosecuting people for marijuana use can be really expensive - think about all the costs of bringing someone in, letting them go, and then going through the court process. Some cities might be hesitant to make that investment, even if it would free up some money for other important things.

Take Denver, though, which is a pretty open-minded place. They've seen a financial boost since decriminalizing marijuana, which they can now use for education, social programs, and helping those in need. It's not just about the money, though - there are plenty of reasons why marijuana shouldn't be legal everywhere. For instance, it could lead to more smoking and driving, which is a big concern. Plus, marijuana is still generally seen as taboo in many societies, so having it out in the open could be uncomfortable for a lot of people.

As for the effects of marijuana and alcohol, it's hard to generalize because everyone reacts differently. Some people have a harder time with moderation, while others can handle it just fine. In terms of driving and decision-making skills, alcohol tends to have more of a negative impact, but marijuana can have a bigger impact on people's lifestyles. Ultimately, when it comes to substances, there's no one-size-fits-all answer because people respond differently.

To be honest, I'd say yes to [the idea of allowing priests to be married] because a lot of the traditional practices within the Catholic Church have been around for a long time, and it's great to have a sense of tradition. However, it's also essential to be open to change and adapt to new ideas. One thing that's always concerned me is how strict the Church can be, not just with its rules but also in judging those who don't follow them perfectly. I'm talking about how they treat people from other faiths, like my parents, who were Episcopalian and Catholic respectively, but couldn't get married in the Church because of my father's background. This lack of tolerance seems hypocritical, especially considering the Catholic teaching of loving others. It seems like the doctrine and practice don't always align, especially when it comes to outdated rules.

While I think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, I'm not convinced that it would necessarily stop pedophilic behavior. People who engage in such acts tend to do so regardless of their marital status. It's a separate issue altogether, one that's not directly related to whether or not someone is married. Allowing priests to be married wouldn't magically fix the problem, and it's unlikely to make a difference in the long run.

It's true that some people might do whatever they want, regardless of their marital status. If someone has a tendency to harm children, they'll probably do so whether they're married or not. So, I don't think allowing priests to marry would be a solution to this issue. It's not a simple fix, and it's not something that can be solved by a single change in the Church's rules.

Honestly, I'm still unsure about this topic.  I haven't given it much thought yet, so I don't know if either side is right or wrong. This issue seems to be the most challenging one we're facing. It's tough to navigate the separation of church and state, especially when it comes to defining marriage, without offending anyone. I'm not sure what the answer is, but I think that civil unions might be the way to go. I'm not convinced that marriage should be regulated by the government, especially since it's often viewed as a sacrament. If it were just a civil union, people wouldn't get special tax breaks or treatment just because they're married.

In my opinion, the government shouldn't care about the specifics of the marriage as long as it's between two consenting adults. It's not their place to interfere with the separation of church and state. If two people want to get a civil union, that's all that matters.

I also think that making gay marriage a federal law would be a good idea if all states can come to a logical agreement. However, a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage seems ridiculous. It's a big issue for some people, but it's not big enough to warrant altering the constitution.

It's just not that crucial to amend the constitution to define or ban gay marriage. It's really not that important.

I don't have an opinion on this either.

I come from a Christian background, but to be honest, the topic of homosexuality is a bit of a complex issue for me. On one hand, I have close gay friends, so I've had a chance to understand their perspective. While I don't necessarily agree with their lifestyle, I do think it's something that should be legalized. I don't think it's a matter for the federal government to decide, but rather something that each state should determine on its own.

I believe this is because different states have different values and opinions. Democratic states are likely to support gay marriage, while Republican states may not. If you live in a state that has decided to legalize gay marriage, I don't think it's right to disagree with their decision, especially since you chose to live there. I think everyone, regardless of their orientation, should have equal opportunities, which is why I believe it should be left up to each state to decide.

I do disagree with President Bush's stance on banning gay marriage, and I don't think it's right for him to impose his views on the entire country. He can't make decisions for every state, and his ban is unlikely to be in place forever. A new president could come in and repeal it, so why not let each state decide for itself? They're the ones who will have to live with the consequences of the decision, not the president. Ultimately, I think it's up to each state to make its own choice on this issue.

Honestly, I'm not at all in agreement with this. Let me think for a moment. I suppose it's worth noting that Myspace is a public platform, and by posting something there, you're basically sharing it with the public. If you look at the definition of a bulletin, it's essentially a post intended for others to see. So, if you post something online, you have to be aware that it's going to be seen by others, including school officials, even if it's not under the school's name. They could still access it from their homes, after all. 

In my opinion, if school officials are monitoring the internet to prevent a school shooting, I think it's perfectly fine that they're doing it. It's their responsibility to keep students safe, and if that means checking Myspace, I don't see it as an invasion of privacy. I mean, if they're looking through Myspace to catch students engaging in underage drinking or other prohibited activities, I do think that's an invasion of privacy. However, if it's to save lives or make the school a safer place, I don't consider it an invasion at all.

I think it's a lot easier to express myself when I'm writing, and it's true that Myspace is a public platform. If a student posts something on Myspace and then gets in trouble for it, that's not unusual. I'm careful about what I post online, like even in emails. I'm worried that something I say could come back to haunt me later.

If you post something as a college student, it's likely to follow you for the rest of your life. Once it's on the internet, it's there forever, and there's no taking it back. If you do something that gets you in trouble, you'll have to face the consequences. I don't think this is an invasion of privacy, because as I said before, Myspace is a public platform. What I'm saying is that I don't think school officials should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have a legitimate reason to do so, like to make the school a safer place, then that's okay. When parents drop their kids off at school, they expect it to be a safe environment, and that's what the school officials were trying to achieve in this case. They were just taking precautions to prevent something bad from happening, like a school shooting.

My teacher discussed this with me at my public high school, and they said it's their responsibility to ensure the school is safe. They did drills and lockdowns in case of a terrorist attack, and it's similar to what happened with the school shooting. They were just trying to make the school a safer place, and that's what the school officials were doing in this case – taking steps to prevent anything bad from happening.

Honestly, I've had time to reflect on our decision to go to war, and my perspective has shifted. To be frank, I was initially all for it because it was a deeply personal issue for me, especially after 9/11. I felt a strong desire to make a difference and cause chaos, just like they had done to us. However, I now think we overlooked the long-term consequences and rushed into it without a clear plan.

I believe that the emotional toll of 9/11 clouded our judgment, and we went in unprepared. Unfortunately, this led to a disastrous outcome. I've come to realize that as long as the different factions over there are fighting each other, they won't be a threat to us. We shouldn't be there to try to fix their problems; instead, we should focus on our own security.

To be honest, I've lost interest in the conflict and those people. It's hard to care about their struggles when they can't even cooperate with each other. I think we went in there with a misguided sense of purpose, fueled by emotions rather than reason. We were looking for revenge, and President Bush seemed to be driven by public opinion and a desire to take action. However, I understand his perspective at the time.

I don't think we had a choice but to respond to the situation, but I do think we could have done it differently. We should have had a clearer plan for creating order and a more unified effort. Unfortunately, this wasn't the case, and we ended up creating more chaos.

Honestly, I don't think we're capable of changing those people; they're stuck in their ways. We're just prolonging our own suffering by staying there. We've made some progress, but not enough to justify our continued involvement. In the end, it's only a matter of time before things fall apart, and we can't stay there forever. I genuinely believe we're doing more harm than good by remaining there.

To be honest, I think the Catholic Church needs to make some changes. Their views on certain issues might be causing them to lose followers. I think this is because the Church isn't very accepting of many things. For instance, when it comes to gay marriages, abortions, and birth control, the Church has very strong views, but they may be a bit outdated. If they adapted to a more modern perspective, they'd likely worry less about losing their following.

I've noticed that some people are starting to turn against the Church due to their stance on these issues. This is because people have different views on these subjects, and they feel that the Church is holding the wrong views. For example, if someone supports abortion, they might not feel comfortable in a community where it's seen as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone believes in gay marriage, they might not want to be part of a community that doesn't agree with that.

It's interesting to think about why the Church is against things like female priests and priests being married. However, I'm not sure if that would have prevented the issues they're facing. Maybe if priests were allowed to be married or if women could be priests, things would be different, but I'm not convinced it would have made a significant difference.

I don't see why priests can't be married, considering the Church views them as being married to God and devoted to their lives as priests. It's like any other job - people have their professional lives and their personal lives. The fact that priests can't have both seems outdated.

Honestly, I have to admit that I've given this a lot of thought, and I don't actually have an issue with gay marriage. In my opinion, people's sexual orientation isn't something they can consciously choose, so I don't think they should be held accountable for it. It seems unfair to deny two people of the same sex the right to get married just because of their sexual orientation. I mean, think about it - people are born with their sexual orientation, just like I'm straight and others are gay. It's not something they can switch or change at will. I don't think the government should be involved in this, as it's not a matter of security or morality - it's a personal issue that doesn't concern them. To me, it's just about treating people with respect and allowing them to live their lives as they are. I don't think the government should be able to dictate who can and can't get married based on their orientation. It just doesn't seem right to me.

In fact, it's kind of simple - the government shouldn't interfere with people's personal lives unless it affects the country's security or well-being. But this isn't about that. It's about two people loving each other and wanting to get married. I don't think the government should be in a position to deny them that. It's just common sense, you know? Let people be who they are and live their lives without the government breathing down their necks. It's really not that complicated.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that I think it's wrong to deny gay people the right to get married. It's just basic human decency. They shouldn't be punished for being who they are, and the government shouldn't be involved in their personal lives. It's as simple as that.

I'm not going to sugarcoat it - I think the government is overstepping its bounds by trying to dictate who can and can't get married. It's not their call. People should be free to love who they want and get married to whoever they choose, without the government getting in the way.

I'm not going to dwell on this anymore, but I just wanted to share my thoughts. I hope that makes sense.

I strongly believe that gay marriage should be legalized because, honestly, there's no valid reason not to. People often think that homosexual couples pose a threat to the traditional family, but that's just not true. It's like comparing apples and oranges - they're two distinct things that can't be equated. Each side of the coin is unique, and it's not fair to judge one over the other. The truth is, homosexual couples have the same rights as everyone else, like having their partner by their side in times of need, even in a hospital or when it comes to tax laws and healthcare benefits.

It's ridiculous that partners in a same-sex relationship can't be considered family in the eyes of the law. They're committed to each other, and that's what matters most. Scientific studies have shown that gay couples have the same success rates and satisfaction in their relationships as heterosexual couples, which is a clear indication that love is love, regardless of orientation.

The problem lies in the fact that homosexual couples are asking for a marriage certificate, a legal document provided by the government, not a church ceremony. If we're allowing civil unions, why not marriage? It's like segregation - separate but unequal. Gay couples are no different from straight couples in many ways, like the roles they play in their relationships.

Of course, there are concerns about adoption, community acceptance, and the impact on children, but these are just new issues that we're still learning about. However, it's hard to deny the fact that children from gay parents are just as capable and deserving of love and respect as any other child. In fact, some schools in cities like New York City even have special programs for kids from gay parents because they face bullying and harassment in public schools.

The real issue is that the government should take a stand on this matter and make gay marriage legal nationwide. The current amendment opposing it is a clear example of hypocrisy, as it goes against the principles of equality and freedom that America claims to uphold. The controversy surrounding the "under God" pledge shows that people are willing to challenge laws that enforce religious standards, so why not apply the same logic to gay marriage?

One of the main reasons people are against gay marriage is the misconception that being gay is a result of psychological damage or a personality defect. However, the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims, and it's time we listen to the experts rather than popular opinion or personal biases. If we did, we'd see the world in a different light and recognize the beauty of love in all its forms.

Okay, let's get this straight. I work in a hospital pharmacy over the summer, and I want to make one thing clear: just because a drug is illegal doesn't necessarily mean it's bad. I mean, think about it - there are plenty of prescription meds that are controlled substances, like oxycodone, Vicodin, and Percocets. We use them all the time to help people, and that's exactly what I think we should be doing with marijuana.

It's not like marijuana is that different from other substances that are abused, like alcohol. Sure, abusing it can lead to problems, but so can abusing alcohol. It's a tough one, I'll admit it. But I think we should take a step back and look at the benefits of marijuana. If we could remove the stigma around it, people might use it responsibly, especially for medical purposes. It's not some evil substance like heroin or cocaine - it's got its own set of risks and benefits.

If we're going to make it available to the public, it shouldn't be all or nothing. A gradual approach might work better, but first, we need to change the way people think about marijuana. It's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, and if we can get past that, maybe we can use it to help people instead of shunning it. That's my two cents, anyway.

I think the church has really adapted to the 21st century, it's not as strict as it used to be. I've noticed this change since I was a kid, going to church every Sunday, dressed in my cute little outfit and matching accessories. I went to a private school and church was a big part of my weekend routine, seeing my friends there was always a highlight. Now, they've introduced a shorter mass for teenagers, which is only 30 minutes long, and people dress in casual attire, especially during summer. It's become more laid-back, even at morning masses where I used to dress up, now people wear jeans and khakis. I think this shift is noticeable, it's the biggest change I've seen. As for other things, that's pretty much it, I don't really know the church's politics, but that's my take on it. 

Regarding the accusations of pedophilia against Catholic priests, I don't think allowing female priests or married priests would have prevented these situations. There are men who are married and still become pedophiles, it's not about their marital status. It's the individual's choice to become a priest, and there are other religions where they can be married. If someone wants to practice their faith and be married, they might consider a different faith. I think pedophilia is rooted in genetics, people are born with these tendencies, and it's not something that can be hidden or changed through marriage. The church can't prevent something that's innate, and if they knew about it and covered it up, that's unacceptable. However, I don't think they always knew. As for other thoughts on the Catholic church, I don't really have any.

At first, I was somewhat okay with the idea, but I think the country was still reeling from the aftermath of the September 11th attacks. It seemed like we entered Iraq using it as a pretext, with various reasons leading us into the conflict. I believe the Bush administration initially linked the Iraq war to Osama Bin Laden and the 9/11 attacks, claiming Saddam Hussein had WMDs, which has since been proven false.

This really bothered me, and the Iraq war just gets my blood boiling. It seems like the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and still hasn't taken responsibility for those lies. Even Colin Powell, who gave that pivotal speech at the UN, now admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence at the time he presented it. To me, that's a serious abuse of power and an impeachable offense.

I think the Bush administration has a disregard for the constitution and has been working to undermine it since 9/11. They came into office with a clear intention to go to war. When I think back to that time, it's clear that the administration had it out for Saddam Hussein, partly due to a grudge carried over from his dad's administration, and also to expand our energy supply – which is a very underhanded approach.

I'm not sure how long this can go on, but I believe withdrawing now could be problematic, as there's a good chance the country would descend into civil war, resulting in more deaths. The current alternative, where the UN and US are considering a coalition of surrounding nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to restore order, doesn't seem like a great idea to me. This could create more long-term issues, particularly with Iraq's sovereignty, as it appears the interim government is disintegrating. The news reports suggest the Parliament is ineffective, and the Prime Minister has little control over the situation.

With groups like Mugtada al-Sadr's party holding significant power in the Iraqi Parliament and radical elements vying for control, the political process is experiencing significant friction. I'm not sure I can articulate all the issues in polite conversation, but it's clear this is a complex and messy situation.

I'm really struggling to find the right words on this. Okay, let's get the basics out of the way first. To be honest, I don't know much about the Iraq War. I mean, it wasn't officially declared as a war, which already makes it tricky to discuss. I think it started as a sort of revenge for 9/11, targeting the people we believed were responsible. But, to be frank, I don't follow this closely, and I'm not sure about all the details. As far as I understand, we're trying to build a democracy in Iraq, making it more like the US, and also securing oil resources. However, this approach is causing a lot of tension and distress.

We're stuck between a rock and a hard place. If we stay, we'll be tasked with building a democracy, which can't be done overnight, and it'll take a lot of time and effort. But, if we leave, the Iraqis will be left to deal with the mess we created, and they'll blame us for it. I'm not sure what the right course of action is, to be honest.

This topic is really challenging for me because I don't know enough about it, and I'm not sure where to start. If you have any points you'd like me to focus on, I'd appreciate it.

To be honest, I think the war should be considered over, not just because of the lack of a formal declaration, but also because it's become more about showing our power and military might than achieving a genuine goal. It's like we're using force to prove a point, rather than working towards a solution.

I'm torn, though. On one hand, I think we should help the Iraqis, but on the other, I worry about the resources we're wasting and the potential consequences of our actions. I feel sorry for President Bush, as this war is making him look really bad, much like the Vietnam War did. It's like history is repeating itself.

It's hard for me to say whether I want the war to end or continue, because I think about all the families who have loved ones fighting in Iraq, and I don't want to see them hurt. However, I also think that our presence is causing more harm than good, as we're disrupting their culture and creating more divisions among the different groups in Iraq. I worry that our attempts to impose our way of life on them will only lead to more resentment and hatred towards the US.

In the end, I think this conflict will drag on for years to come, and it's hard to see a clear solution. That's about all I have to say on the matter.

Honestly, I don't think it's right for the government to make it a law or even recognize it as legal. I believe it's up to the churches to decide, especially considering the constitution clearly states the separation of church and state. It's a pretty straightforward principle that's been set in stone, and I think trying to impose any kind of authority over it would be a direct defiance of what's already been established.

To me, allowing government to dictate what churches can and can't make illegal is essentially favoring one church's beliefs over another. It's clear that a lot of Catholics and Christians are against it, and it's mainly being opposed in certain areas like Boston. I don't think it's the government's place to decide what's acceptable or not within the church.

The separation of church and state is a fundamental aspect of the constitution, allowing for religious tolerance in the United States. I think trying to amend the constitution to restrict this principle would be wrong and contradict the existing values. It's one of the few amendments that would actually restrict the people rather than limiting government power, which is exactly the opposite of what it's supposed to do.

Personally, I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. I believe the president's push for an amendment is mainly driven by his own Catholic beliefs and personal views. It's showing a preference for one religion over others, which I don't think is fair. The churches should be the ones making these decisions, not the government. There's no clear reasoning behind this amendment other than personal opinions, and I don't see how it would benefit the economy or society.
